title: Eat Your Way to Good Teeth
text:
Eat Your Way to Good Teeth

Just as you’ll find certain foods damaging to your teeth, so will you find specific foods beneficial to your teeth. These types of foods promote oral health and make your pearly whites look like you’re meant for Hollywood’s big screen. So what should you stock up on to keep your teeth in “good shape?”

Chew on These

Fruits

The best fruits for your teeth include cranberries, raisins, and apples (of course!). Cranberries, according to a study published in the Caries Journal, lower the risk for cavities. Thanks to the presence of polyphenols, cranberries prevent plaque from fixing to your teeth by slowing down bacteria growth. Raisins, meanwhile, contain phytochemicals. Phytochemicals destroy cavity-causing plaque bacteria.

Apples, on the other hand, can cleanse and brighten your teeth. This is attributed to the mild acidic nature of the fruit that acts as an astringent for your pearly whites. Also, apples are pretty crunchy, which lead to a whole lot of chewing. Chewing can disturb dental plaque, which means the insidious “beasts” don’t stick around, causing your teeth harm.

Cheese

Yum. Cheese, it turns out, is not just delectable to your tummy but valuable for your teeth, too. A study published in General Dentistry reveals that cheese can prevent cavities. The delightful dairy product increases pH levels in the mouth; higher pH levels lower the chance of getting cavities.

Leafy Green Vegetables

Kale and spinach promote good oral health because they contain calcium and folic acid. Calcium builds your teeth’s enamel while folic acid can treat gum disease, particularly with pregnant women. You can eat them in stir fries and salads, or drink them up in smoothies for a power breakfast or pre-workout beverage.

Almonds

These super tasty nuts are high in protein and low in sugar. So you will definitely want to have them in your “dental diet.” Instead of snacking on salty chips or deadly sweet pastries, try almonds.

Drink Up!

Tea

Like cranberries, tea contains polyphenols. But don’t just drink any old tea. Choose black and green teas. A study from the University of Illinois discovered that people who rinsed with black tea every day had less plaque buildup than people who rinsed only with water. The Journal of Dental Research also adds that black tea can fight halitosis.

Milk

If you listened to your mom about drinking milk, then you probably have fantastic teeth now. The American Dental Association shares that drinking a glass of milk daily can lower levels of acid, which is good for your teeth.

title: The New-Old Organizing Tool Perfect for Hillary Supporters
text:
The New-Old Organizing Tool Perfect for Hillary Supporters

In recent campaigns, whether it’s a congressional campaign or presidential campaign, the fundamentals of voter contact are phoning and canvassing. It’s how I began as a volunteer (running a volunteer phone bank) and it’s what we measure in our contacts with voters leading up to elections. Voter contact is important. And, yet, every campaign is different and requires adaptation to meet the unique nature of each campaign. This year, as a supporter of Hillary Clinton, in addition to phoning for voter contact, I’ve been experimenting with hosting house parties — purposeful house parties — for Hillary, which leads me to say,

“If you support Hillary Clinton for President, then start hosting house parties.”

Last June I had the opportunity to hear a presentation by Stephanie Schriock of EMILY’s List, where she shared polling data on voter knowledge of Hillary. Most voters know who Hillary Clinton is and so she has very high name id. Surprisingly very few voters know what she’s done. We’re talking people who only think of her as the former First Lady, who don’t know about her full career as an attorney, child advocate, Children’s Defense Fund employee, US Senator from New York, and even as the Secretary of State in President Obama’s Cabinet.

I might have been skeptical of this statement had I not encountered this very phenomena at the 2008 caucuses. At my precinct caucus in 2008 a woman who was supporting then Senator Obama told me that, “being First Lady doesn’t qualify you to be President.” I recall my brain flashing to counter arguments like she’s been a senator longer than Barack Obama has been, and then flashed to the reality that this woman is not going to change her mind and I shouldn’t waste the short time we have to negotiate with someone who is already decided. That memory validated in a very personal way what Stephanie was telling us statistically. People need to know more about Hillary’s life experiences and that type of engagement takes more time than a phone call or talking with someone at their front door.

That was when I decided to host a house party for others who are supporting or interested in supporting Hillary Clinton. At the first house party in July my goal was to help educate people on Hillary’s bio, just the facts of who she is and what she has done. Ironically, to do so, I ended up expanding my knowledge of Hillary Clinton as well. (And here I thought I knew all about her.)

A former campaign colleague on another presidential caucus campaign created an episode of Jeopardy! where the topic was our candidate and facts about his career. It was fun and effective. As a campaign manager for congressional candidates, I used this and other games to help the campaign staff learn the information we needed to know.

Playing a fun game is a much better way to remember the information than reading a flat bio or listening to someone else read it.

For the July Hillary house party, I worked with another supporter to create the questions for the Jeopardy! board with the topic, Hillary Clinton. I was nervous about it because it’s one thing to tell people you’re working with that they “get” to play this game, and another thing to tell invited guests. Fortunately, they were all open to it. We formed two teams and offered old campaign pins as prizes. Everyone was engaged and brought their competitive spirit to the rounds. One person commented on leaving, “This is the first time I’ve actually learned something at a campaign house party.”

Since then, I’ve held a house party every month, with different people attending. September was another round of Jeopardy! with different categories, including adding information about the many different plans Hillary had rolled out during the summer months. Based upon questions from the participants, October was loosely styled like a trivia game, where the questions required higher level thinking skills and were focused on her policy plans.

November was the first of a series on caucus strategies, with a nod to the tradition from rural caucuses of a chili potluck. Unlike other caucus trainings, this one focused on reading the room, what to think about and how to use the information in front of you to inform the conversations with others in ways that will most help Hillary.

More importantly, when I’m calling Democrats in my precinct, I always tell them about some of the things going on in our own neighborhood and invite them to come to the next house party. It’s a great way to engage people in a conversation and to let them know that it’s happening here in their neighborhood. (And, yes, I do leave messages with my phone number and information about the next house party if no one answers the phone.)

If someone had told me a year ago that doing this would be helpful to Hillary Clinton’s campaign, I would have laughed and scoffed and probably said something like, “House parties are for fundraising, not for organizing.” Well, things change and hosting a house party for Hillary supporters is a good thing to do.

As Hillary supporters, we’re not just working to win the Iowa Caucuses or to secure the nomination, we want to see Hillary Clinton as our next president. Voters make their decisions on whom to support based on a variety of factors, including what influential friends know about a candidate. You, dear reader, can be that influential friend by hosting a house party. You’ll have fun and you’ll help Hillary.

As public and vocal supporters, we need to be well informed about our candidate and we need to help inform others. And we need to be open to doing what it takes to help others share our understanding of Hillary.

“If you support Hillary Clinton for President, then start hosting house parties.”

title: A Recap on the Democratic Debate
text:
The second Democratic debate, hosted by CBS News, proved fast-paced driven by productive, tough questioning toward the three Democratic candidates: former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders, and former Maryland Governor Martin O’Malley.

After the tragic Paris attacks the prior evening, CBS News understandably made national security and foreign policy a top priority for the first part of the debate. The evening began on a somber note, with the candidates and lead moderator John Dickerson expressing their condolences through a moment of silence.

Soon after, the candidates ran head first into their first disagreement: terrorism and ISIS. Sanders felt that then New York Senator Hillary Clinton’s 2002 vote for the Iraq Invasion was responsible for Iraq and the Middle East’s situation with ISIS. However, Clinton blames the disbandment of the Iraqi army and said ISIS cannot be “contained,” but rather have to be “defeated.”

In the mix of this, Sanders supports his claim that climate change is the greatest threat toward national security and says that it directly relates to terrorism.

O’Malley is asked if he, having no foreign relation experience, could handle such a dangerous world. He quickly responses by attacking Clinton for the world being dangerous, although he didn’t mention her name (his response also ignores the question).

Either way, all of the candidates were pivotal on using radical “jihadists” rather than the term “radical Islam,” before turning to refugees. O’Malley pointed out he was the first candidate on the stage to call for the United States to take in 65,000 Syrian refugees. Clinton, who also supports the U.S. taking in refugees, says that all refugees should be vetted and screened.

The debate then moves to various different directions including Wall Street, Clinton’s millions of dollars worth of speeches and e-mail use, the corrupt finance system, health care, and education.

In summary, Clinton discusses how she will pay for family paid leave and health care breaks. She mentions taxing the wealthy more and closing corporation loopholes and deductions as a few strategies. O’Malley mentions that his state raised sales tax to get stuff done and Sanders reiterates that large corporations and the wealthy will pay their fair share in order for them to pay for his presidential plans.

While Sanders aspires to “scrap” Obamacare and move to a single-payer system, Clinton states that it is unrealistic. Instead, she feels that the focus should be on preserving the Affordable Care Act and working to improve it.

On the topic of guns, O’Malley talks about what he did in Baltimore to make it safer, while Clinton hit Sanders on his support of a 2005 bill that granted immunity to gun manufacturers. A short-lived cat fight ensues with O’Malley accusing Clinton of taking “three sides” on the gun debate.

In my opinion, Sanders improved since his last debate, answering questions far more effectively and with greater detail this time around. However, voters are looking for policy specifics and he simply couldn’t provide details for his makeover on healthcare and college.

As someone who openly endorses Clinton, I feel that her supporters got what can be described as a win. In response to tough questions, she remained calm with her answers and provided an effective rebuttal when attacked. She was also able to cite her foreign policy experience when topics of terrorism and national security came up.

Overall, the debate proves how productive debates can be and with that, I look forward to many more so Americans can see discussions and branch out to conversations about the candidate that best fits their vision.

Brett Blair is a contributor for Slash Magazine, a website for teens, by teens which launches on November 30, 2015!

title: Win or Lose, Bernie Will Benefit the Most From Last Night’s Debate
text:
Win or Lose, Bernie Will Benefit the Most From Last Night’s Debate

Via Five Thirty Eight

If you vote Democrat and your name is not Joe Biden, chances are good that you went to bed happy after CNN’s Democratic debate last night.

That’s because unlike the Thunder Dome-style Republican debates, there were no clear-cut eviscerations like one could expect from any debate in which Donald Trump is involved.

So then why did almost every headline across the Internet this morning read that Hillary Clinton was the obvious winner of last night’s Democratic debate?

Surely, CNN, Time and Slate saw their own polls that showed views siding with Bernie Sanders by a long shot … Well, except maybe CNN who deleted their poll in the morning, and replaced it with a story titled, “Hillary Clinton’s Big Night on the Debate Stage.”

Interestingly, that headline doesn’t quite match up with their post debate coverage, which showed CNN’s Facebook survey and focus group all considering Bernie Sanders the sure debate winner.

Shoutout to Redditor u/brendantheraven

So what is going on?

Let’s be clear: Hillary Clinton had a great night — she nailed most of her obvious talking points, she wasn’t attacked too harshly by any candidate — or arguably even Anderson Cooper — and like a well trained politician, she navigated curveballs acceptably.

But one thing she didn’t do, which in the long run she desperately needs to do, is give voters a reason to vote for her that they don’t already have.

Voters going into last night’s debate with their minds made up, were not going to be swayed — be they Bernie fans, or Hillary fans.

But here is Hillary’s problem: she’s the establishment. In any other cycle that would be fine, but if her waning poll numbers are indicative of anything, it shows that a portion of her voters are up for grabs. Sanders doesn’t have that problem.

In the Long Run, Bernie Sanders Won the First Democratic Debate

For many voters, Bernie Sanders is a hard sell; and rightly so. But his fiery rhetoric is captivating to those who can identify with his message. Look no further than the record setting crowds at his rallies, or the impressive amount of small dollar donors his campaign drew in just a few months. Its safe to say that when you go Bernie, you don’t go back.

And debates have consequences that go far beyond stage time, and for Bernie Sanders, there’s no where to go but up. Here is why Bernie Sanders won the first Democratic debate:

1. He got the quote of the night.

By now you have probably heard that Bernie Sanders is “sick of hearing about your damn emails” Hillary Clinton. That line was a gift to Hillary , but Sanders will surely reap the benefits. Why? Because it speaks directly to who he is as a candidate: No B/S —2016 voters like that.

2. In the first 24 hours after the debate, his campaign raised $2 million.

That goes to show that he inspired people. Many progressives have been living in a Bernie-bubble the last few months, but it is important to remember that many still don’t know who he is, or what he is about — just that he is a challenger to Hillary Clinton. But last night was his first real shot at captivating a national audience; and if money is any indicator, he struck a chord.

3. He won the internet vote.

Despite what Donald Trump said, any Google analytics, or Twitter trend, or Facebook trend, showed Bernie Sanders was creating the most online buzz. Oh not to mention, the word “socialism” gained some traction on Google too… most just wanted to know what it meant.

4. He got people excited.

CNN’s post debate focus group was full of voters who loved Bernie’s performance. People who were previously ready for Hillary, were fired up by Bernie Sanders, and switched sides. One voter even said he was convinced the country would be a little better off with a dash of Socialism.

So does that speak for the rest of Democratic voters? See sections 1–3.

So Where Does Bernie Go From Here?

All this good news for Sanders fans shouldn’t amount to more than just that — good news. Sanders still has an uphill battle ahead of him, wether the media is on his side or not. Last night was an overall win for him, but he still fumbles a bit on issues of gun control, and the scarlet “S” pinned to his jacket is still seen as a general election death sentence.

But as far as the first debate goes: hate it or love it Hillary, but last night the underdog was on top.

title: Hillary Clinton Thinks You Are Very Dumb
text:
Last night, Bernie Sanders asked why Hillary Clinton’s foremost campaign donors have been Wall Street banks. I’ve linked a video of the exchange below, but here’s a transcript of what he said:

I have never heard a candidate — never — who has received yuuuge amounts of money from oil, from coal, from Wall Street, from the military-industrial complex, not one candidate says, “Oh, this campaign contribution will not influence me. I’m gonna be independent.” Well, why do they make millions of dollars in campaign contributions? They expect to get something, everybody knows that. Once again, I am running a campaign differently than any other candidate. We are relying on small campaign donors, 750,000 of them, thirty bucks apiece. That’s who I’m indebted to.

This is a good question! Generally speaking, people will contribute to political campaigns they support. Banks enjoy being profitable. By extension, they will thus support policies (and, necessarily, politicians) that will bolster their bottom lines. So, it poses the question: When four of Hillary’s top five campaign donors are Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and Morgan Stanley, who’s being played a fool? Presumably, it’s not the very wealthy people whose entire careers revolve around buying things to advance their own self interest, so, Sanders is saying, perhaps it’s the populace at large for believing Hillary when she suddenly professes a new love for regulating banks.

Here is Mrs. Clinton’s response:

He has basically used his answer to impugn my integrity, let’s be frank here. You know, not only do I have hundreds of thousands of donors, most of them small, and I’m very proud that, for the first time, a majority of my donors are women — 60 percent of them. [Applause.] I represented New York, and I represented New York on 9/11, when we were attacked. Where were we attacked? We were attacked in downtown Manhattan, where Wall Street is. I did spend a whole lot of time and effort helping them rebuild, that was good for New York, it was good for the economy, and it was a way to rebuke the terrorists who had attacked our country. [Applause]

Let’s be totally clear, here: Hillary Clinton only felt comfortable offering that bucket of word-turds as an answer because she thinks you are very stupid. She thinks you are an easily-distracted child, and she does not respect you.

I think it’s fine that women are donating to Hillary’s campaign! I’d rather introduce publicly-funded elections, but if we’re going to have a broken system, we might as well have gender parity. (We do it with overpolicing and CEOs, as well. This is liberalism in 2015, refusing to tackle the roots of problems like your favorite sportsmen refuse to tackle their rivals’ quarterback.)

But what in the world does any of that have to do with Wall Street? If I ran for President and took money from Satan, aka The Actual Devil, could I say, “Well, a majority of my contributions are from people who are not the Dark Lord, Harbinger of the Absolute Nothing, Prince Of All That Is Ghoulish, so, never mind?” Of course not. Why is everyone clapping?

Emboldened, Hillary seized the opportunity to make a cartoon a reality in a way that even Rudi “9/11” Giuliani would balk at. I get that it’s a Presidential debate, so we’ll have to be reminded of how you were in charge during what is possibly the worst day in our nation’s history — why is this a thing politicians keep doing, by the way? I don’t remind everyone of the time I managed a McDonald’s that burst into flames — but my god, you were asked about campaign contributions. What does this have to do with 9/11? What is the causal relationship here?

WHY IS EVERYONE CLAPPING?

It’s because she’s right. We are easily-distracted children, and we will get the President we deserve.

(Quotes via YouTube.)

title: CONGRESSMAN MO BROOKS’ SPECIOUS ARGUMENTS FOR IMPEACHING HILARY CLINTON SHOULD SHE BE ELECTED…
text:

Huntsville, AL 35803–2426

Contrary to inaccurate media portrayals of my statements to the contrary, the issue I address is not the September 11, 2012 Benghazi terrorist attacks. Nor is the issue about emails and email servers. Rather, it is about Hillary Clinton’s improper handling of classified documents and the risks such mishandling poses to America’s national security and American lives.

All of this reminds me of President Bill Clinton’s impeachment. Bill Clinton and the leftist Democrat news media went all-out to persuade the American people that Bill Clinton’s misdeeds were about “sex” and “lying about sex” (which we all know men do). Bunk! While Bill Clinton’s political deception was effective, the issue was not about “sex” nor was it about “lying about sex”. Rather, Bill Clinton committed the “high crime and misdemeanor” of felony perjury in a federal court proceeding, a form of obstruction of justice (for which President Nixon was removed from office).

Now Hillary Clinton and the leftist Democratic news media use the same obfuscation and minimization strategy when she claims it is about “emails” and “email servers” . . . which very few American citizens understand or care about. Bunk again! Hillary Clinton’s offense is not about emails and email servers, it is about knowingly and intentionally mishandling classified documents which, if they fall into the wrong hands, put America’s national security and American lives at risk.

Hillary Clinton’s conduct is so serious, so dangerous, so evil, and so wrong, that there are numerous federal statutes that prohibit it.

By way of background, and as you may know, in March 2013, a Romanian cyber-hacker named Marcel Lazar Lehel, aka Guccifer, asserted access to Hillary Clinton’s unsecure private email server which she used in violation of federal law to conduct sensitive state department business as Secretary of State. The issue of Clinton’s vulnerable email server was discovered during the House Select Committee on Benghazi’s investigation into the deaths of four Americans in the Benghazi terrorist attacks. Secretary Clinton’s gross mishandling of classified information via her illegal use of an unsecure server (left vulnerable to hacking and foreign surveillance) is a serious national security threat that puts innumerable American lives at risk.

According to Article II, Section 4 of the U.S. Constitution “The President, Vice President and all Civil Officers of the United States, shall be removed from Office on Impeachment for, and Conviction of, Treason, Bribery, or other high Crimes and Misdemeanors.”

In my judgment, Hillary Clinton will be a unique president in that, if she is elected by the public next November, the day she is sworn in is the day she could be subject to impeachment due to her prior commission of high crimes and misdemeanors.

For emphasis, Hillary Clinton’s putting classified documents on an unsecure email server in her home in Chappaqua, New York (and, perhaps, elsewhere) violates federal law! Period. End of subject. No further debate needed.

After revelations of Clinton’s unusual email arrangement, the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) began a criminal probe into whether classified information stored on the server had been compromised upon referral from the U.S. inspector general. Though Clinton attempted to obstruct justice, and the investigation, by wiping her email server clean, the FBI successful recovered a significant portion of the deleted data from the server hard disk after seizing it from a small Colorado based IT company.

While the FBI probe coincides with House Benghazi Committee investigations, the two are otherwise wholly unrelated.

In a New York Post article dated August 5, 2015, former federal prosecutor Bradley Simon is quoted as saying, “If it is proved that Clinton knowingly sent, received or stored classified information in an unauthorized location, she risks prosecution under the same misdemeanor federal security statute used to prosecute former CIA Director Gen. David Petraeus.” In my view, Clinton’s intentionally receiving, storing and/or sending numerous classified documents vulnerable to surveillance by America’s geopolitical foes is a far worse offense than that for which General Patraeus was convicted.

The United States Inspector General has also opened an investigation into Clinton’s unlawful conduct. In a July 23, 2015 memo, Charles McCullough, the inspector general for the intelligence community, voiced concerns over information that passed through Clinton’s email server. McCullough said the data should have been treated with greater sensitivity, since it was derived from classified information produced by the U.S. intelligence community.

Clinton’s only stated defense of her endangering the lives of American’s has been to obfuscate by claiming she never sent or received emails marked classified. Clinton’s presidential campaign communications director Jennifer Palmieri said in a statement, “Hillary only used her personal account for unclassified email. No information in her emails was marked classified at the time she sent or received them.” For emphasis, while Hillary Clinton’s “the documents were not marked ‘Classified’ defense” makes for good political soundbites, it is no legal defense at all. As a matter of law, and although emails may not have been so marked, the classified nature of the material is undeniable.

Stated differently, Hillary Clinton is a former U.S. Senator. As a U.S. Senator, she absolutely knew the standards for classification of national security information. She also knew how important it is to America’s national security and American lives for that information to only be kept in secure locations that are impenetrable to our geopolitical foes. As Secretary of State, Hillary Clinton had a double dose of instruction concerning proper protection of classified documents.

Yet, in the face of all of this instruction and warning, Hillary Clinton intentionally and knowingly stored, received, and/or sent classified documents in violation of governing federal statutes. These statutes are criminal in nature.

Further, Hillary Clinton’s declaration that, as Secretary of State, she at no time used email to transmit sensitive information with national security or foreign relations implications is unsubstantiated by senior investigators. Charles McCullough has made clear that at least one email, if not more, contained information that only could have come from the intelligence community. McCullough stated, “We note that none of the emails we reviewed had classification or dissemination markings, but some included [intelligence community]-derived classified information and should have been handled as classified, appropriately marked, and transmitted via a secure network.”

What’s worse, according to an Associated Press article dated October 13, 2015, classified information on Clinton’s email server was so vulnerable it was accessed by low skilled hackers without great difficulty. The article reads, “Clinton’s server, which handled her personal and State Department correspondence, appeared to allow users to connect openly over the Internet to control it remotely, according to detailed records compiled in 2012. Experts said the Microsoft remote desktop service wasn’t intended for such use without additional protective measures, and was the subject of U.S. government and industry warnings at the time over attacks from even low-skill intruders.”

The AP article goes on, “Some emails on Clinton’s server were later deemed top secret, and scores of others included confidential or sensitive information. Clinton has said that her server featured ‘numerous safeguards,’ but she has yet to explain how well her system was secured and whether, or how frequently, security updates were applied.”

William Johnson, a former Air Force officer who served at the state department from 1999 to 2011, stated in a New York Times article, “If I’d done that, I’d be out on bond right now.”

Further, I have spoken to numerous Department of Defense civil servants and contractors in the Tennessee Valley who deal with classified information on a daily basis. To a person they have told me that, had they handled sensitive material the way Hillary Clinton did, they would have been fired from their jobs on the spot and would have been subject to criminal prosecution. They also tell me that they are very upset with the double standard President Obama, the White House and the executive branch have employed in protecting Hillary Clinton versus how these Tennessee Valley employees would have been treated, and how they have seen others treated, for mishandling classified documents in a much less dangerous way than Hillary Clinton handled classified documents.

The intentional and careless way in which Hillary Clinton handled information vital to national security and endangering American lives is unacceptable and punishable by law. Should Hillary Clinton win the presidency, her callous disregard for federal statutes designed to protect America and American lives from the loss of classified information meet the Constitution’s impeachment standard of “high crimes and misdemeanors” and immediately subjects Hillary Clinton to the risk of impeachment proceedings the moment she is sworn in.

Again, thank you for sharing your insights on this issue. Feel free to contact me again in the future. You may wish to visit my website at http://brooks.house.gov/ for additional information about issues and legislation before Congress.

Sincerely,

Mo Brooks

Member of Congress

title: Sen. Chuck Grassley Joins the Hillary Email Non-Scandal Circus
text:
Sen. Chuck Grassley Joins the Hillary Email Non-Scandal Circus

The Right-Wing Congressional Circus has a new ringmaster: Iowa Senator Chuck Grassley.

Since the House Benghazi Committee, led by Trey Gowdy, failed so spectacularly in its attempt to find any wrongdoing in Secretary Clinton’s emails (because there wasn’t any), Senator Grassley is now taking a stab at it.

As a reminder, this is after the New York Times issued a frank mea culpa to admit it completely mis-reported the email non-story from the beginning.

…And after the Justice Department said the review of Clinton’s emails was not a criminal investigation.

…And after officials said the investigation is not targeting Clinton — or even suggesting that she did anything wrong.

It should be obvious by now that Republicans are hoping to drag this email non-scandal as far as it can stretch, and they hope it can stretch as far as Election Day 2016.

For evidence that this is a partisan fishing expedition, look no further than the Republican National Committee, which is pressing the State Department to investigate Clinton’s emails further. What reason does the committee — whose sole purpose is to get Republicans elected — have to investigate a former Secretary of State’s emails? Unless, of course, that former Secretary is a formidable Democratic candidate for President who stands in the way of the RNC seizing back the White House?

The latest email-scandal-revival strategy is to zero in on Clinton’s deputy chief-of-staff, Huma Abedin.

Grassley’s one-man “investigation” began as a crass probe into this committed public servant’s time off — ignoring the fact that someone who works for the Secretary of State has a 24/7 job and never gets a day off.

Grassley is asserting that there was some mysterious conflict of interest in Abedin’s role and her prior work for a private company. But, tellingly, his colleagues have refused to follow him down the rabbit hole — and are even telling him he does not have the jurisdiction to carry out his inquisition.

As Minority Leader Harry Reid said two weeks ago, “How much money will Republicans in Congress waste to try and bring down Hillary Clinton?”

It didn’t work the first time they tried, and it won’t work now. The simple fact is, there’s no there there — whatever these circus magicians try to pull out of their hats.

title: Why Do You Hate Hillary So Much?
text:
On Twitter, I’m fairly well-known to many for my anticapitalist tirades and my seemingly inexhaustible well of feminist outrage. My sense of justice is inflamed. I have no fucks left to give for half-ass apologetics.

So when people ask me why I hate Hillary Clinton, the answer should be clear: I think she’s reformist bullshit personified. I think she’s a woman who will lie to millions straight to their face that she cares about them and their struggles while making backroom deals with lobbyists hedging on wordchoice and legalese to make sure she’s never held accountable.

Today, I wake up and find that CNN had deleted every online poll that indicated that the viewers of that debate felt Bernie Sanders won by a landslide.

This is some straight-up Orwellian bullshit, friends.

I think (LOL, I KNOW) they did this because Hillary Clinton is bought by the same corporate bullshit that has bought out our journalism. They’re the same fucking machine churning out the same poll-tested garbage.

But why do I hate Hillary Clinton so much if I’m a Leftist Commie Feminist? Can’t I see what she’s trying to accomplish? She’s struggled! She’s so determined! She’s making the best of a bad situation.

Whatever.

Hillary Clinton has proven to me during this campaign that she’ll say practically anything to win. And because she’ll say practically anything to win, she crosses a lot of lines of authenticity that I will brook from no politician.

As a poor kid growing up in America, I have known no fucking safety net and I have known nothing but a political regime that continually shits on kids like me trying to do the right thing so that middle-class families can have another mortgage deduction. Hillary Clinton is everything I can’t stand in the American Left and she can rot for all I care, feminist or not.

Hillary Clinton is not from the South, but she’ll fake a Southern accent if she thinks that will make you like her.

Hillary Clinton has never known hunger, but she’ll pretend to know if it’ll mean you’ll vote for her.

She has never known what it’s like to work a monotonous manufacturing job with maybe the glimmer of a fucking hope of a 25-cent hourly raise after two years of good behavior.

She has never known what it’s like to stay awake with a toothache for 8 weeks in a row, hoping against reality that it will go away because you don’t have $400 to spend on a cavity.

She has never had to choose between which medications to pay for this month, choosing between pain relief or sanity, as if that’s any choice at all.

She has never watched her daughter suffer through her twenties from long-term unemployment because her connections have made Chelsea’s career success an all-assured inevitability.

She has never known the struggles of most Americans, but she’ll pretend she knows because she thinks that’s what will get her votes.

And fuck, maybe it will.

But I don’t have to like it. I don’t have to stand by and watch her momsplain educational inequity to my generation suffering under Atlassian debt by saying young people should work a few hours a week to pay down their tuition as if working part-time at Waffle House at $7.25 an hour will do fuck anything.

She’ll convince you her ideas are terribly reasonable, but she can’t convince me that her ideas aren’t terrible.

So yeah, you know what? Fuck Hillary Clinton.

We can do better.

title: Arthur, Arthur, Art & Arturito
text:
Thursday, September 11, 2014

Arturito’s girl -Photograph Alex Waterhouse-Hayward

The idea for what promises to be a long blog came to me last Sunday. Both Randy Rampage and

birthday boy Zippy Pinhead kept calling Art Bergmann, Arthur. It struck me that his real friends call him that and for the rest of us Art is enough.

I then wondered how many Arthurs had gone through my life, who I not only photographed but somehow had left something of themselves in me.

So there is Arthur Erickson, Arthur (most called him Art) Phillips and Arthur Bergmann. There is one more.

Arturito Durazo Díaz (33) showed up in Vancouver in 1982. At the time I had some dealings with the unofficial Mexican Tourism Director in Vancouver, Carlos Hampe. I visited Hampe and noticed Durazo sitting behind a desk that had nothing on it in a room that was virtually empty of furniture and decoration. I was introduced to him. He was affable, friendly and interested in the fact that I was a photographer and that I spoke Spanish.

During his stay in Vancouver which was around two years he often came to my house for dinner. He had a passion for jig-saw puzzles. He often stayed for hours with my daughters fitting the pieces to 1000 plus puzzles. Durazo told me he had helicopter pilot’s license and wanted to learn to hang glide. I accompanied him to many of these lessons in Langley. He was brave and he tried to convince me to try. I told him I had no life insurance and since I was a free lancer, any accident would leave my family with no financial support.

My daughters liked him as did my wife Rosemary. One day he showed up with a box full of beautiful Florsheim shoes. He told me that inmates of several Mexican prisons made them and he was starting a business to import them to Canada.

Arturito’s 2005 police mug shot

Any questions I directed to Hampe about his “assistant”, who seemed to do nothing at the office, only resulted in the rolling of his eyes and silence.

All I knew was that Durazo’s father, Arturo Durazo Moreno had been the chief of police in Mexico City, between 1976 and 1982 during the 6-year rule of President López Portillo.

During those 6 years Durazo Moreno’s underlings had to pay their quota of contributions. There was an organization that arrested promising thieves who were protected and of course had to pay their quotas. In some cases these trained thieves and the policemen robbed banks. One of the biggest scandals was the appearance of 13 Colombians in the city’s main sewer. Some had their heads missing; others had been mutilated and tortured.

López Portillo’s successor, President Miguel de La Madrid initiated an investigation and the murders were linked to Durazo who fled the country.

That would explain why his son, also left the country and why Carlos Hampe could do nothing about having the man appear in his office and get a salary for doing nothing. I remember that Arturito had a better car than Hampe. It was a very large Pontiac.

Arturito was a handsome young man. His father was quite ugly and because he was dark-skinned he was called El Negro Durazo. Durazo died in 2000 after having served 6 years (he had been extradited from Puerto Rico, and given a 16 years sentence but because of “good behaviour” and delicate health he served those 6 for drug trafficking, corruption and extortion). At his funeral a police mariachi played a famous song about El Negro Durazo.

As soon as Durazo Moreno died the army generals rescinded his lofty rank of General de División. They had been furious when President López Portillo had celebrated the man with the rank.

But what perhaps riled the usually patient Mexican populace were the many mansions that the Police Chief built. The most famous one La Partenón in Zihuatanejo was said to have gates that had been stolen from the storied Chapultepec Castle (where young Mexican cadets had fought back with heroism but in futility against a well equipped American Army, one of the officers of this army a young Robert E. Lee.). You might know that U.S. Marine Corps song “From the halls of Montezuma…”

La Partenón

In the late 80s a Mexican cumbia band, La Sonora Dinamita recorded a song by its then singer Juliette called El Africano (The African) in which one of the lines “Hey mom, what does El Negro want?” to which then Juliette answers, “Could it be another Parthenon?” Of interest to readers here is the fact that Ray Conniff did an instrumental version of the song called African Safari.

This was my Arturito’s father. In 2005 Arturito was imprisoned for unlawfully taking over a large property. He is now probably out and is on Facebook.

If you look for images of Arturito you will only find one through Google. The Mexican newspapers announcing his arrest have blank squares where his picture should be.

I was never allowed by Arturito to take his picture but he did ask me to photograph his lovely Mexican girl friend who had brilliant bleached blonde hair. I have lost the colour pictures and I have forgotten her name but I did find some negatives which I took with Kodak b+w infrared film.

If I were to run into Arturito I would invite him for dinner and I would take out a box with a 1000 plus piece puzzle.

Link to: Arthur, Arthur, Art & Arturito

title: The Fight for the Metaverse
text:
Project Sansar: The Seasoned General

Last week I spoke with Ebbe Altberg, Linden Lab’s current CEO, who contacted me after viewing my flowchart on the current VR Ecosystem. He wanted me to know that Linden is a contender in this ecosystem with an entirely new virtual reality world — code named “Project Sansar” — that I had not included in the chart. Altberg emphasized that Project Sansar is NOT Second Life 2.0. He wanted to convey that everything in Project Sansar will be a brand new metaverse that conserves only two features from Second Life — the ability for users to easily create and sell content and the Linden Dollar currency system for buying and selling that content.

Altberg said that they could not just convert Second Life into a virtual reality world because of “performance issues” that arise out of “users (not) necessarily know(ing) how to create extremely optimized content like a gaming studio would.” To preserve that key feature for users in a VR environment, Linden Lab opted to create a new platform.

According to Altberg, Project Sansar’s platform will have user-generated content that is more scalable than what was possible in Second Life. He emphasized that scaling content would permit creators to license their work and, thus, generate more revenues. He gave the hypothetical example of Texas A&M creating a chemistry lab inside Project Sansar which could be licensed to other schools who could then customize it to their own needs and desires. When I inquired about software for content creation, Altberg said that Project Sansar content is currently using Autodesk Maya for rendering but Linden expects to change that by consumer launch day. Linden is also working on better discovery, which is a “walled garden” in Second Life, to allow anyone to search for a particular type of experience and link directly to a downloadable form of that experience in Project Sansar.

Linden plans to launch an Alpha version this summer to a few select testers as a PC virtual reality experience and then expects to tackle other platforms.

Why would anyone bet on Project Sansar to win the metaverse battle? I asked Altberg. He responded that Linden Lab has actually been in the virtual worlds trenches, sharpening their tools for 12 years and they have a user-centric, revenue-generating model that Altberg believes will give them maximum strategic advantage. Unfortunately, another major contender enjoys these advantages too because the general of High Fidelity’s army founded Second Life.

High Fidelity: The Experienced Challenger

After founding Second Life and staying for over a decade, Philip Rosedale, left the company in 2013 to pursue his dreams of creating the “next-generation virtual world” which he calls High Fidelity and diverges from Project Sansar’s vision. I have not been able to interview Rosedale but draw insights from key sources.

In his recent talk at SVVR, Rosedale describes the metaverse as something that contains the web itself; it encompasses what we define today as the Internet but it also allows us to live inside of it instead of merely accessing its content. He also believes, not surprisingly given his legacy with Linden, that the metaverse is a shared space where content should be created by its users. This is why he is building High Fidelity as an “open source software for virtual reality.” He wants anyone to be able to quickly generate a virtual space, have others join them inside that space and easily allow them to explore the various virtual worlds.

Like Project Sansar, Rosedale wants to ensure that the virtual worlds are scalable, and recognizes that it is critical to avoid Second Life’s struggles with scaling due to limitations caused by physical servers. In High Fidelity’s architecture blog, they note that they will be operating their servers in an open shared network, allowing many different people and institutions to deploy virtual world servers, interconnecting those servers so that people and digital objects can travel among them, and harnessing shared computing devices to scale their content and load.

Unlike Project Sansar, High Fidelity’s Alpha is already available for download and users can create and deploy virtual worlds, content and experiences. Thus, the experienced challenger has positioned itself on the metaverse battlefield first and may have achieved some strategic advantage that way.

In Rosedale’s talk, he indicated that, like Second Life and Project Sansar, High Fidelity is experimenting with revenue generation as a layer on top of their open network but it is proposed to operate differently than the others. High Fidelity users will be sharing their machines so the revenue model proposed would “create some kind of currency that is valued on computer time.” They have yet to decide whether it will be bitorrent or a blockchain currency. In sum, while High Fidelity has moved quickly to establish a strategic position for its metaverse contender, its Achilles’ Heel, at least at this time, would appear to be its revenue model.

Surreal: The Hungry Underdog

Surreal has no relation to Second Life but is also hard at work trying to create the “first fully immersive virtual world.” Unlike Project Sansar and High Fidelity, Surreal has no immediate plans for content within their virtual world to be user-generated. During their talk at a recent the NYC VR meetup, they said they were open to this but as of right now, that feature is not available. Because their world is built with Unity, they are not tied to a PC experience and proudly proclaim that Surreal will soon be available on any virtual reality device (Google Cardboard included). Currently, you can email them to request a demo version for Oculus.

Another difference is that your Surreal avatar will be tied to your Facebook identity. This provides a way to verify your identity and tie your virtual interactions to your real world social graph. Surreal’s CEO, Arthur Goikhman, clarified that they did this to protect their user’s privacy but would allow options for people to meet outside of their real world social circles.

According to their Facebook page, Surreal’s mission is “to make social games truly social.” Perhaps they want to approach the metaverse from a gaming standpoint, whereas Project Sansar and High Fidelity like to stay away from social gaming comparisons.

During the meetup, they also mentioned they would be monetizing the platform through product placement and selling items, such as clothes or experiences, but didn’t provide any details into how this virtual economic system would work.

Although my information is limited, it would appear that Surreal is the underdog in this battle, but they are hungry and attacking from a different angle. They will need to move quickly to outmaneuver both the more seasoned competitors for there are additional players entering this hotly contested battlefield.

Other companies like JanusVR, AltspaceVR and Next Galaxy are positioning themselves to enter the battle. I will seek more information for a future post on them.

The battle lines are taking shape and the competitors are lining up along them. It’s hard to predict a winner because they are fighting over turf that we cannot yet fully see — regardless of our VR equipment. All this makes for a conflict never before seen, yet classic in its human dimensions.

title: What is the Metaverse and why you want to be part of it
text:
What is the Metaverse and why you want to be part of it

The Metaverse is the future of the Internet. The networked dimension of Virtual Reality.

Internet will be in 3D and this is no news. Even thou the concept of the Metaverse has been imagined, described, written and filmed for many years now, it’s only in the recent years that we are placing the first fundamental building blocks for virtual reality to be developed. Some innovators and notable investors in the Silicon Valley eco-system, have been working for some years on the idea of making a 3D version of the Internet, in other words the first version of the Metaverse. The buzz around VR devices such as the Oculus Rift, are only a part of what is moving around VR. While smart VR devices to simulate movement, presence and other interactions, are very important, what is fundamental for the Metaverse to come alive, is the existence of a platform and system architecture, to sustain it. The processing power we need to power up a virtual reality based Internet, is already there. We only need to connect the dots and leverage the immense calculus potential of the Internet as a whole. This is exactly what some visionaries and architects of the future of the Internet are doing. And this is happening right now. The enablers are there and we are developing the technologies that will allow us to experience a truly immersive Online Virtual Reality experience.

Read more about Virtual Reality on our blog: https://www.qbittech.com/index.php/qbit-virtual-reality-blog

title: The Metaverse as Mediator between Technology, Trends, and the Digital Transformation of Society and Business
text:
The Metaverse as Mediator between Technology, Trends, and the Digital Transformation of Society and Business

Here is an intro abstract and link to a very interesting article, wrote in a collaborative effort between myself and two other Researchers: Sven-Volker Rehm and Lakshmi Goel, for the Journal of Virtual Worlds Research.

In this reflective article we discuss the potential of recent developments in virtual worlds for offering novel value propositions for the digital transformation of society and business. In particular, we consider the role of a Metaverse, understood as a globally accessible 3D virtual space and computing infrastructure — and today still a conceptual vision — as a mediator between technology trends and societal and business applications. We outline how current technology trends can be linked with high-value added application scenarios through the Metaverse as a mediating design space. Our insights project both a push effect, i.e. novel technologies fostering radical shifts in society and business, as well as a pull effect, i.e. radical ideas stimulating technology developments. Leveraging both effects for creating high-value added applications however, requires an integrated, mediating design space, which can potentially be obtained through advances of virtual worlds towards a Metaverse.

Read the full article here: https://journals.tdl.org/jvwr/index.php/jvwr/article/view/7149?utm_source=Journal+of+Virtual+Worlds+Research+Announcements&utm_campaign=9dfd81deef-Futures_is_Published&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_328ce3bba8-9dfd81deef-335680333

title: The Fight for the Metaverse, Part II
text:
What if the “fight for the metaverse” is actually less like a battle to the finish and more like a foot race in which the competitors have enjoyed different start times and stagger marks? Recall from my last post on “The Fight for the Metaverse, Part 1, I characterized a few companies engaged in an all-out battle for colonizing and dominating the metaverse — High Fidelity, Second Life’s Project Sansar and Surreal. What I’ve continued to learn is that these companies are better understood as those who got into the race earlier and now enjoy varied head starts but additional competitors are in this race too.

These newbies include: ConVRge, JanusVR, VRChat and AltspaceVR. Will they catch up? What will it take? Just greater speed or will they also have to be more agile, scrappier and determined? Perhaps, they will they change the course of the race itself.

On Your Marks, Get Set, GO!

ConVRge founders, Shawn Whiting and Hayden Lee, began developing ConVRge’s current interface about 6 months ago in Unity (a development platform used to create 3D and 2D games and interactive experiences) when they threw their first event, a virtual dance party. People from all over the world entered ConVRge as floating heads (their version of an avatar) identified by username. What they quickly realized was that it didn’t matter if the person’s head icon was a moon, someone’s realistic looking face or an animation. People loved the interaction in this platform because when they moved their head in real life to look at someone or something, the movement was mirrored in the virtual reality world. In the VR industry, this phenomenon is known as head-tracking.

With the success of their first virtual party meetup, the founders have turned these interactions into a staple of their social VR community. Each week they host a weekly virtual campfire meetup for people to come and socialize about whatever is on their minds, with no specific agenda or topic. Every two weeks they host a developer talk, where they bring an expert to talk about a topic of high interest, which attracts many newcomers. ConVRge has a particular strategy to its race tactics: instead of allowing people to explore various worlds, they have focused on building one main interactive space. The space looks like a valley, trees scattered around the hill-tops with a large screen floating in the middle to allow all avatars to watch together.

Photo Inside ConVRge

In some sense, this single room philosophy is a different metaverse than what Neal Stephenson defined in Snow Crash, “an immersive virtual world so complex and convincing that it would seamlessly and intimately interconnect to the ‘real’ world”.

In contrast to ConVRge, JanusVR’s race strategy seems premised on facilitating user autonomy and innovation. Founder of JanusVR, James McCrae explains that “JanusVR is reimagining how we use and interact with the internet.” JanusVR is building “a virtual reality interface to the internet” in which “web pages are rooms, and links connect rooms via portals.” Moreover and unlike all other metaverse contenders who are building with Unity, JanusVR uses HTML and Javascript because it wants to be “the Firefox, IE and Chrome in this virtual internet story” explains Nukemarine, a JanusVR contributor, on Zapchain.

The antithesis of a walled garden, JanusVR’s decentralized approach is to be a hyper-open development platform, focused on empowering their users to easily build and create new 3D environments into what McCrae calls a “fertile creative ground”. The developer community naturally gravitates towards this flexible environment, as demonstrated on their highly active Reddit page. JanusVR contributors are also encouraged to use websites like VRSites, a VR hosting and development platform, or SceneVR, which is making VR apps with HTML and JS, to also plug into JanusVR. According to Nukemarine, JanusVR plans to sprint ahead of other metaverse front runners by allowing you to connect into any platform (even competitors’) from JanusVR, something that none of the others (currently) allow.

Photo Inside JanusVR

The third new runner in the metaverse race is VRChat. Their strategy is best characterized as a combination of particular features found in the other two already discussed. Founders Graham Gaylor and Jesse Joudrey are bullish on users creating their own virtual worlds; however, unlike JanusVR, they use Unity arguing that it produces the best look and feel. The user-generated locations are an array of unique experiences, ranging from lush floating islands to large theatres.

Gaylor told me that the current version of VRChat began about 8 months ago. However, they have big plans in the next couple weeks to revamp the overall design of the entire experience. Below is an image of what the current design looks like:

Photo Inside VRChat

In a recent interview on Voices of VR, Joudrey said that “Social VR is a feature, not a platform”, which is why they built a VRChat SDK with a set of Unity scripts to “help easily add social experiences to your VR experience.” They believe that in order to get everyone into the “metaverse”, they have to make a system that is easy to build for in a short amount of time. Currently, they are known for having many playful elements built by their users, including a hoverboard and their glowing orb interface, which allows a user to open up a portal to another location and invite the users in the current room to be teleported together to the next location. This glowing orb interface also appears in JanusVR in the form of portals. Ready Player One, much?

Like ConVRge, they host weekly meetups which they announce on Twitter and Reddit. Their most well-known weekly meetup is called “Gunter’s Universe”, which occurs in front of a “virtual studio audience” comprised primarily of VR developers.

Now I turn to AltspaceVR, the company that recently raised $10.3M, grand totaling to $15.5M and distinguishing it from the other three who have yet to (publicly) raise capital. AltspaceVR has been spurred ahead by cheerleaders in the media and a strong community of developers and enthusiasts. Known for their robot avatars with distinctively hued fronts (iconic as un-customized avatars), they’ve been more focused on creating shared experiences than the aesthetics of their avatars. A step the company is taking in that direction is testing collaborative game playing in virtual spaces — including chess and Dungeons and Dragons. Outside of games, they keep their events page stacked with upcoming social AltspaceVR gatherings, where you can schedule an event of your own or register to attend one with others on the platform.

AltspaceVR’s CEO, Eric Romo told RoadToVR that “AltspaceVR wants to enable the creation of VR experiences with the same ease of web development.” Unlike JanusVR and VRChat, however, they have not yet allowed for users to create their own worlds or avatars and upload them to AltspaceVR.

Photo Inside AltspaceVR

A greater leap is their new browser extension. Imagine you find exciting content on the web and want to experience it in VR. With a click of the AltspaceVR extension, you can access that webpage in AltspaceVR and share it immediately with your friends. It’s as simple as bookmarking a page, yet allows you to experience your favorite content in a whole other dimension.

The Takeaways

One comes from Eric Johnson’s interview with Palmer Luckey, quoting him saying that “the term ‘metaverse’ is a bit undefined. For any one company to say, ‘We are building the metaverse’ is pretty hyperbolic. Building all the pieces is going to be hard, and the way you imagine things in sci-fi doesn’t always translate over to the way things will be in the real world.”

Perhaps there is no end to this race or as Luckey describes, there might not be just “one” race, but many different tracks that may one day connect together. The one sure thing is that in order for these companies to keep running on any track, they need to build a strong community that will cheer them during the upcoming laps and spur them to move faster more strategically. Without a strong community, any social VR company will be left in the dust.

We’re in the early phase of innovation for not only social VR, but the entire VR industry. Their journey of treading through the unknown landscape of social VR, will impact not only the future of VR but will help define what the next version of the consumer Internet looks like. As we analyze this industry, we must all remember that VR is in its infancy; it’s similar to the state of the mobile industry 12 years ago when the PalmOne launched.

title: 6 Reasons You’re Ready For An Epic Bike Journey Today
text:
6 Reasons You’re Ready For An Epic Bike Journey Today

somewhere in taiwan

If you’ve followed my wanderings and adventures on Instagram, then you know I’m all about bike travel. Whether you’re trekking across a state, or across the country, a bike trip opens up a whole world of badass discovery and adventure. I’m also a believer that traveling long distances by bike is something that just about anyone who wants to, can do. My bike touring philosophy is based on the idea that you don’t need a lot of money or expensive gear to have an incredible journey. So if you’ve ever considered taking a bike trip of your own, but haven’t taken the plunge, I’ve got six reasons why you might already have everything you need to set off on a bike adventure right now.

1. The Bike

This is where conventional wisdom starts to creep in and ruin the party. Don’t be fooled, an epic bike trip doesn’t require flashy, new bicycles. I purchase all of my bikes through Craigslist. The last two major trips I cycled were down the Pacific Coast and from Saint Louis, MO to Brooklyn, NY via Canada. Both of these trips were done with two different bikes priced at a whopping $40 each. Thanks, Craigslist! Obviously, If the latest and greatest bicycle works for your budget (or you already own one), more power to you! For everybody else, keep in mind that it’s not necessary at all.

2. Gear/Equipment/Camping

We live in an exciting world saturated with sexy, new technology, bike gear, and space age camping accessories. These are all nice (like, really nice), but you can do without these; especially if that sweet, new solar charger from REI is going to break the bank. There are all kinds of ways to support your tour without forking over all of your adventure cash. After my first set of panniers began falling apart, I opted to incorporate discarded things instead of buying a new pair. I began using milk crates and oil cans to carry my stuff. This is a much cheaper (read: free) and recycle-friendly way to travel compared to traditional panniers. You’re bike won’t win any beauty contests, but that’s not why we’re here, is it? Besides, I actually prefer the DIY Mad Max-ian look and feel of a touring bike put together from reclaimed and recycled objects.

For shelter, I suggest a tent (more on this later). I’m currently using a tent I purchased from a thrift store for $15. Additionally, I’ve used sleeping bags that ranged in price from $0 to $5. Just about anything you need for camping and bike travel can be found in mom and dad’s garage or your local thrift stores. However, If I do spend a little extra cash on anything, it usually goes to a solid rear and/or front rack.

3. Fitness

I know some cyclists out there that have pre-tour training regiments; the idea being that you need to be in shape, or at the very least, train hard before going on a bike trip. While I understand the reasoning behind this, I’d like to challenge this notion. Sure, you could train for hours every day, or you could simply just… go. The beauty of a bike trip is that it is YOUR journey. YOU get to decide how fast and far you want to travel every day. Remember, It’s not a race. Your body will have plenty of time to adapt to life on the road. No training needed. None. Seriously, all you need is a bit of time in the saddle, and you’re ready to bike across the country. I Promise :)

4. Accommodation

While biking from Saint Louis, MO to Brooklyn, NY I didn’t pay a single dime for accommodation. How? I spent the majority of my nights either bundled up in my tent, or sleeping under the stars in my sleeping bag. Where? Anywhere and everywhere. All it takes is a bit of imagination and some common sense. I found plenty of space behind stores, parking lots, fields, playgrounds, churches, schools, abandoned buildings, and even on an interstate construction site. And no, I was never mugged, attacked, followed or feared for my safety at any time. In fact, I’ve met some really incredible people during my urban camping experiences, including a homeless fisherman who insisted that I put my tent up next to his truck so he could watch over me and my stuff while I slept on the docks.

5. Food and Water

If you’re biking in the USA, this is easy. Food and water are EVERYWHERE. Most of the food I eat comes from dollar stores and discount shops. This means a lot of bootleg peanut butter sandwiches and off-brand cookies. If the cardboard-esque taste of name brand-less oreos doesn’t quite do it for you, there are the classic alternatives: gas stations, supermarkets and other chain grocery stores. For the more hardcore cyclists among us, dumpster diving is an easy option. And it’s probably a lot healthier than my own touring diet. For more info on dumpster diving and bike travel, check out this dude → Rob Greenfield.

As for hydration, water is clean and free all over North America, and can be found just about anywhere: libraries, gas station bathrooms, parks… anywhere. Drink up!

6. Lycra/Spandex

Completely unnecessary

There it is

I’ll end by saying that none of this is gospel. Adopt all of these ideas, some of these ideas, or none of these ideas. Use whatever bike you’d like, stay in hotels or slum it in a tent, eat whatever you want, and if you look hella fabulous in spandex, then by all means go for it! For me, travelling by bike isn’t about living a life with rigid rules designed by someone else, it’s about freedom and living an adventure on your own terms.

Agree? Disagree? I’d love to hear your thoughts! Do you have any questions or comments about bike touring? Please leave a comment or tweet a brother up at @JoshTk_
